importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article indicates the current status of the flooding crisis in Mexico, providing up-to-date information on the death toll and response efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding and its effects occurred over a previous week, highlighting the duration and severity of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz has confirmed 29 deaths; Hidalgo 21; Puebla 13; Queretaro 1.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed to assist affected areas, with coordination between governors.
Approximately 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers having 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
The Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have jointly responded, distributing food and clean water by air where roads were blocked.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply in the five affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.

namedEntities.name: Mexico
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in North America experiencing a severe flooding disaster
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary location of the disaster, affecting multiple states and involving national-level response efforts.

namedEntities.name: Veracruz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in southeastern Mexico affected by flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the most severely impacted states, with 29 deaths and 18 missing people.

namedEntities.name: Hidalgo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in central Mexico affected by flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported 21 deaths and 43 people missing, indicating significant human and infrastructural impact.

namedEntities.name: Puebla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in central Mexico affected by flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Saw 13 deaths and 4 missing people, with extreme rainfall in Cuetzalan del Progreso.

namedEntities.name: Queretaro
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in central Mexico affected by flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported one death, indicating minimal but still present impact.

namedEntities.name: Laura Velazquez Alzua
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief of the National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided official updates on death toll and missing persons during the presidential briefing.

namedEntities.name: Claudia Sheinbaum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She led the national response by coordinating military deployment and addressing public concerns about early warnings.

namedEntities.name: National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Mexican government agency responsible for disaster response
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as the central body reporting on deaths, missing persons, and coordination of emergency aid.

namedEntities.name: Hurricane Priscilla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Remnant tropical system contributing to the flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Contributed to the extreme rainfall that caused rivers to rise and landslides.

namedEntities.name: Tropical Rainstorm Raymond
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tropical system contributing to the flooding
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Together with Hurricane Priscilla, it caused the heavy rainfall that led to severe flooding.

namedEntities.name: Cerro Azul
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Veracruz that received extreme rainfall
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported 280mm of rain, one of the highest rainfall amounts in the affected areas.

namedEntities.name: Cuetzalan del Progreso
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Puebla that received extreme rainfall
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Received 286mm of rain, the highest rainfall recorded in the region, contributing to severe flooding.

namedEntities.name: Mexican Army
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Military branch involved in disaster response
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Deployed to assist in rescue, food, and water distribution in inaccessible areas.

namedEntities.name: Mexican Air Force
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Military branch involved in disaster response
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Participated in air-based delivery of essential supplies to flood-affected regions.

namedEntities.name: National Guard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Military branch involved in disaster response
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Joined forces with the Army and Air Force in delivering emergency aid.

namedEntities.name: Electricity officials
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Government officials responsible for power recovery
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported that nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity supply after outages.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Mexico, heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding across five states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas were Veracruz, with 29 deaths and 18 missing, followed by Hidalgo (21 deaths, 43 missing), and Puebla (13 deaths, 4 missing). The National Civil Protection Coordination, led by Laura Velazquez Alzua, coordinated a national emergency response involving thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, to deliver food, water, and emergency aid. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm respectively. Approximately 100,000 homes were affected, and about 263,000 people lost power, though over 80% of electricity supply has been restored by repair workers. The government has also faced criticism over the lack of early meteorological warnings indicating such extreme rainfall.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
